==Japanese==

===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=とまと}}
{{borrowing|ja|sort=とまと|en|tomato}}. The kanji are {{ateji|sort=とまと}}, from the {{etyl|zh|-}} word for {{m|en|tomato}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=irr|とまと|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|トマト}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=とまと|rare}} {{alternative spelling of|lang=ja|トマト|nodot=1}}: [[tomato]] (fruit)

=====Usage notes=====
The kanji spelling for ''tomato'' is exceedingly rare.

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|ばん|か|yomi=kanyo}}
Given the history of when tomatoes were introduced to the far east, probably from late-middle or early-modern {{etyl|yue|ja|sort=ばんか}} {{m|zh|蕃茄}}. Compare the modern {{etyl|yue|-}} reading of ''faan<sup>1</sup> ke<sup>4</sup>''.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=kanyo|ばんか|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|ばんか}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=とまと|rare}} [[tomato]] (fruit)

=====Usage notes=====
This term has been superseded in modern Japanese by the English-derived {{ja-r|トマト}}.
